body:
Hi welcome~ 

There are two main schools for translation, one that tries to be the most literal word by word, and one that tries to translate meaning line by the line. (And also there are bibles that insert commentary and such.) The former is more “accurate” and the later is more vernacular. I would recommend daily reading in the first kind and perhaps supplement with the second kind if you are having some trouble with a verse. 

So I’d recommend the NASB, the ESV, or the NJK. And then the Passion translation or the Message for a more vernacular translation. 

Some bibles have concordances which show where the same word is in the Bible for cross referencing and comparing verses on the subject. 

When people are doing close up study of theology in passages they will also look at the meaning and cultural context of a word in its original language. You would likely hearing sermons with commentary like this. In general would encourage learning history and cultural context with your bible reading. People often seek commentary from other pastors and theologians on areas they like more of a perspective on. The more you read the Bible, the greater understanding you will have of overarching principles such as God’s character and personality. No worries or anything if that seems advanced, I’m just letting you know if you have trouble understanding stuff at the start that there can more to learn. 

If you don’t know where to start reading, I would recommend reading Genesis and Exodus and the Gospels (Matthew, Mark, Luke, John). Proverbs is also a very straight forward book of wisdom and Psalms has poetry. 

Some helpful short video explanations:

https://youtu.be/tU_BuZhWBl0

https://youtu.be/bmO0Fwa74QM

God bless and come back with any further questions you might have if you like :)

body:
Truth for Life is offering an extremely affordable copy of the English Standard Version.

https://www.truthforlife.org/store/products/books-and-booklets/shareable-esv-bible/?src=20AIYELA5

I don't have any complaints with the ESV other than that I tend to use the NKJV by personal preference.

If you want a Bible on your phone or computer I actually really like the Olive Tree Bible app. 

https://www.olivetree.com/

It pushes quite a few adds your way that may actually be of interest if you're exploring the Faith and want more resources, but it's not intrusive about it. It has quite a few modern translations available for free including the NKJV and the ESV I've already mentioned; and it gives you the ability to directly compare them.

The best Bible software I've ever found is theWord, but since it is so incredibly customizable it can take quite a bit of setup before you land on a layout and resource list you're comfortable with.

https://theword.net/

One last thing that I would recommend, check out C.S. Lewis' Mere Christianity. It's not anything like exhaustive; it's just a good way to get your feet wet, but very few Christians I've ever known take real issue with anything said in it, and it shows a lot of the essentials in an easy to understand package. Plus it comes in an even shorter abridged version called What Christians Believe if that is more your bag.

https://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_nkw=mere+christianity&_trksid=p2380057.m4084.l2632&_sacat=171243

https://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_nkw=lewis+what+Christians+believe&_trksid=m5467.l1311&_odkw=lewis+what+Christians+believe
